title: Celtic and Celtic Englishes
hypotheses: Two-wave Celtic substrate influence hypothesis - early medieval and modern contact periods
notes: Systematic analysis of progressive aspect and it-cleft constructions as evidence for Celtic substrate influence. Argues for continued contact influences between Celtic and English across historical periods.
strengths: Comprehensive theoretical framework, systematic feature analysis, historical periodization
weaknesses: Limited quantitative evidence, relies heavily on typological similarity
citation: Filppula, M., & Klemola, J. (2017). Celtic and Celtic Englishes. In Varieties of English (Vol. 5). De Gruyter Mouton.

title: English and Celtic: contact-induced change in history
hypotheses: Systematic contact-induced change through specific sociolinguistic mechanisms
notes: Overview of English-Celtic contact research with taxonomic classification of contact scenarios and linguistic effects. Emphasizes geographical and temporal dimensions of contact.
strengths: Comprehensive methodological framework, systematic classification of contact types, cross-linguistic perspective
weaknesses: Primarily review/synthesis rather than new empirical data
citation: Hickey, R. (2020). English and Celtic: contact-induced change in history. Linguistics Vanguard, 6(s2).

title: Celtic influence on Old English and West Germanic
hypotheses: Extensive and sustained Celtic-Germanic contact with specific sociolinguistic transmission mechanisms
notes: Critical analysis demonstrating that Celtic-Anglo-Saxon contact was more extensive than traditionally assumed. Establishes sociolinguistic mechanisms for substrate influence through bilingual communities and language shift scenarios.
strengths: Rigorous historical analysis, detailed sociolinguistic reconstruction, extensive documentation
weaknesses: Limited corpus-based quantitative analysis
citation: Lutz, A. (2009). Celtic influence on Old English and West Germanic. English Language & Linguistics, 13(2), 227-249.

title: To be, or not two be's? Celtic substrate influence on the Old English copula
hypotheses: Celtic substrate influence correlates with demographic intensity of Celtic populations in different OE dialect areas
notes: Corpus analysis of Old English copula usage patterns across dialects. Demonstrates correlation between Celtic population density and substrate effects in North, West, and Midlands regions.
strengths: Quantitative corpus analysis, systematic dialectal comparison, demographic correlation
weaknesses: Limited to single grammatical feature, undergraduate thesis level analysis
citation: Bradley, L. (2011). To be, or not two be's? Celtic substrate influence on the Old English copula. Queen Mary's OPAL, 28.

title: The Influences of the Celtic Languages on Present-Day English
hypotheses: Chronological stratification hypothesis - substrate features entered English during distinct historical periods
notes: Comprehensive analysis of temporal dimensions in Celtic substrate influence. Argues for stratified process rather than single contact event, with different features entering at different historical periods.
strengths: Systematic chronological analysis, comprehensive feature coverage, methodological innovation
weaknesses: Master's thesis level, limited peer review, some speculative elements
citation: Niehues, J. (2006). The Influences of the Celtic Languages on Present-Day English. Magisterarbeit, Philipps-Universit채t Marburg.

title: Celtic Influences on the English Progressive Form
hypotheses: Celtic substrate origin for English progressive aspect development
notes: Detailed analysis of parallels between Celtic and English progressive constructions. Systematic comparison of native development, Latin, French, and Celtic hypotheses for progressive aspect origin.
strengths: Systematic hypothesis comparison, detailed linguistic analysis, clear methodology
weaknesses: Not peer-reviewed publication, limited historical documentation
citation: Lim, J. (2017). Celtic Influences on the English Progressive Form. Academia.edu.

title: English Auxiliaries: Structure and History
hypotheses: English auxiliary development follows non-Germanic patterns consistent with Celtic systems
notes: Foundational analysis of English auxiliary system development within comparative Germanic framework. Demonstrates that English auxiliary patterns are unprecedented in Germanic but consistent with Celtic grammatical systems.
strengths: Authoritative scholarship, comprehensive historical analysis, comparative Germanic perspective
weaknesses: Published before recent advances in Celtic hypothesis research
citation: Warner, A. R. (1993). English Auxiliaries: Structure and History. Cambridge University Press.

title: The Rise and Fall of Constructions and the History of English Do-Support
hypotheses: Do-support as unique English characteristic requiring special explanation
notes: Analysis of do-support as uniquely English phenomenon. Questions why do-support developed in English but not other Germanic languages, suggesting special historical circumstances.
strengths: Rigorous formal analysis, cross-Germanic comparison, construction grammar approach
weaknesses: Doesn't explicitly consider Celtic substrate explanation
citation: Culicover, P. W. (2008). The Rise and Fall of Constructions and the History of English Do-Support. Journal of Germanic Linguistics, 20(1), 1-52.

title: Grammaticalization paths of periphrastic 'do'-constructions
hypotheses: English do-support follows Celtic-type grammaticalization pathways
notes: Cross-linguistic analysis of 200 languages showing do-periphrasis patterns. Demonstrates that English-type do-support exhibits specific properties aligning with Celtic rather than Germanic patterns.
strengths: Large cross-linguistic sample, systematic typological analysis, grammaticalization focus
weaknesses: Limited historical depth for English-specific analysis
citation: J채ger, A. (2007). Grammaticalization paths of periphrastic 'do'-constructions. Studies van de BKL, 2007, 353-380.

title: Celtic influence in English? Yes and No
authors: Robert D. Borsley, Maggie Tallerman, David Willis
hypotheses: Celtic substrate influence on English response particle systems
notes: Analysis of English Yes/No response patterns showing divergence from Germanic systems. Demonstrates that English response patterns mirror Celtic systems and represent Late Middle English innovation.
strengths: Systematic comparison with Germanic languages, historical corpus analysis, clear Celtic parallels
weaknesses: Limited to single grammatical feature
citation: Borsley, R. D., Tallerman, M., & Willis, D. (2009). Celtic influence in English? Yes and No. English Language & Linguistics, 13(2), 251-270.

title: Early contact and parallels between English and Celtic
hypotheses: Integrated methodological approach combining multiple lines of evidence for substrate influence
notes: Establishes critical methodological foundations for Celtic substrate research. Argues for integrated approaches combining historical sociolinguistics, comparative-historical linguistics, and corpus-based analysis.
strengths: Methodological innovation, systematic framework development, rigorous standards for evidence
weaknesses: Primarily methodological rather than empirical contribution
citation: Hickey, R. (2000). Early contact and parallels between English and Celtic. In Sounds and Systems (pp. 1-32).

title: Contact and the History of Germanic Languages
hypotheses: Celtic substrate effects as part of broader contact-induced change patterns in Germanic
notes: Comparative analysis of contact-induced change across Germanic languages. Demonstrates that Celtic substrate effects in English are part of broader patterns operating according to predictable sociolinguistic principles.
strengths: Comprehensive Germanic perspective, systematic contact linguistics framework, theoretical integration
weaknesses: Broad scope limits detailed English-specific analysis
citation: Roberge, P., & Hickey, R. (2020). Contact and the History of Germanic Languages. Wiley.

title: An Evaluation of the Celtic Hypothesis for Brythonic Celtic influence on Early English
journal: Master of Philosophy thesis, Australian National University
hypotheses: Systematic evaluation of Celtic substrate claims using corpus-based quantitative methods
notes: Comprehensive evaluation employing systematic corpus analysis to test substrate claims. Emphasizes quantitative analysis and statistical validation, moving beyond impressionistic observations.
strengths: Rigorous quantitative methodology, systematic evaluation framework, comprehensive coverage
weaknesses: Master's thesis level, conclusions somewhat skeptical of substrate claims
citation: Owen, J. M. (2018). An Evaluation of the Celtic Hypothesis for Brythonic Celtic influence on Early English. Master of Philosophy thesis, Australian National University.

title: The Celtic Hypothesis - Do we actually speak British?
hypotheses: Digital humanities approaches to revealing substrate influence patterns
notes: Corpus-based evidence using digital humanities approaches to reveal previously hidden patterns of substrate influence through large-scale textual analysis.
strengths: Digital humanities methodology, large-scale analysis, systematic approach
weaknesses: Not peer-reviewed publication, limited theoretical framework
citation: Rivas, M. (2017). The Celtic Hypothesis - Do we actually speak British? UNED.

title: What else happened to English? A brief for the Celtic hypothesis
hypotheses: English exhibits complexity reduction patterns characteristic of contact-induced change
notes: Influential argumentation for Celtic hypothesis based on complexity reduction patterns. Argues that English exhibits contact-induced changes rather than internal Germanic development patterns.
strengths: Clear theoretical framework, systematic argumentation, influential in field development
weaknesses: Some controversial claims, relies on typological arguments
citation: McWhorter, J. H. (2009). What else happened to English? A brief for the Celtic hypothesis. English Language & Linguistics, 13(2), 163-183.

title: World lexicon of grammaticalization (2nd edition)
authors: Tania Kuteva, Bernd Heine, Bo Hong, Haiping Long, Heiko Narrog, Seongha Rhee
hypotheses: Cross-linguistic databases enabling systematic comparison of grammaticalization pathways
notes: Comprehensive database of grammaticalization pathways across 1,009 languages. Enables systematic comparison revealing that English patterns often align more closely with Celtic than Germanic systems.
strengths: Massive cross-linguistic database, rigorous methodology, computational resources
weaknesses: General resource rather than English-Celtic specific analysis
citation: Kuteva, T., Heine, B., Hong, B., Long, H., Narrog, H., & Rhee, S. (2019). World lexicon of grammaticalization (2nd edition). Cambridge University Press.

title: Grammaticalization of periphrastic constructions
hypotheses: Contact-induced grammaticalization requires usage-based and construction grammar approaches
notes: Theoretical analysis establishing frameworks for analyzing contact-induced grammaticalization. Moves beyond traditional historical-comparative methods to incorporate usage-based and construction grammar approaches.
strengths: Theoretical innovation, methodological advancement, construction grammar integration
weaknesses: Primarily theoretical rather than empirical
citation: Wischer, I. (2008). Grammaticalization of periphrastic constructions. In Studies on Grammaticalization (pp. 241-252). De Gruyter.

title: Contact-related processes of change in the early history of English
journal: The Cambridge Handbook of English Historical Linguistics
hypotheses: Systematic contact-related change processes in early English development
notes: Comprehensive analysis of contact-related processes in early English history within authoritative handbook context. Provides systematic framework for understanding Celtic substrate influence.
strengths: Authoritative handbook chapter, comprehensive coverage, systematic framework
weaknesses: Handbook format limits detailed analysis depth
citation: Klemola, J., & Filppula, M. (2016). Contact-related processes of change in the early history of English. In The Cambridge Handbook of English Historical Linguistics (pp. 361-377). Cambridge University Press.

title: The Question of a Hamito-Semitic Substratum in Insular Celtic and Celtic from the West
hypotheses: Multiple substrate layers in Celtic languages affecting subsequent English contact
notes: Analysis of pre-Celtic substrates in Insular Celtic languages, relevant to understanding the substrate linguistic environment during Celtic-English contact periods.
strengths: Novel theoretical perspective, deep historical analysis, substrate layering approach
weaknesses: Not peer-reviewed, highly speculative, indirect relevance to English
citation: Hewitt, S. (2019). The Question of a Hamito-Semitic Substratum in Insular Celtic and Celtic from the West. Academia.edu.

title: Language change in early Britain: the convergence account
hypotheses: Convergence model for understanding Celtic-English contact outcomes
notes: Recent theoretical development proposing convergence model for understanding language change in early Britain. Focuses on Northern Subject Rule and other contact phenomena.
strengths: Recent theoretical innovation, systematic convergence model, empirical grounding
weaknesses: Limited scope to specific features, relatively new theoretical framework
citation: Hickey, R. (2022). Language change in early Britain: the convergence account. In Sounds and Systems (pp. 185-197).
